config.question: Why did most men and women in early Massachusetts aspire to full membership in churches though they were voluntary institutions?

choices.content: Membership entitled them to receive the sacraments and gave them certain rights in their church.
The members of the church were entitled to an annual financial incentive.
Obtaining a membership in the church was not a demanding process and was granted based on residence.
The church acted as an intermediary for trade and a membership was essential for trading.

answer_3.response: Full membership entitled men and women in early Massachusetts to receive the sacraments and gave some of them responsibility for choosing ministers, disciplining sinners, and settling difficult questions of theology.
